First Repentance: On the Killing of Living Beings

Today, in this Daoist ritual arena, all present turn their minds toward the Compassionate Honored One, repenting the karmic offenses of killing living beings.

The repentant master, [Name], gathers his mind, kneels in reverence, and listens attentively to the scriptural words:

All sentient beings, so long as they dwell within the human realm, remain entangled in the web of the world. Having never encountered a virtuous friend and constantly associating with the foolish, they accumulate habits that become deeply ingrained. Like the mingling of fragrant and foul, they are stained by manifold transgressions. They give free rein to reckless cruelty, perpetrating suffering without cause, never awakening a heart of compassion. They kill living beings, devouring flesh and bone.

At times, for the sake of parents, themselves, brothers, wives, children, or extended kin, they gather in villages and hamlets, slaughtering countless beings without a thought for their lives.

They kill cattle, sheep, mules, horses, pigs, dogs, and other domesticated creatures, those raised and fed by humans. They boil and butcher deer, foxes, rabbits, tigers, leopards, and wolves—those dwelling in mountains and forests—slaughtering the six kinds of livestock without a moment’s hesitation, heedless of whether they are fat or lean.

Some pierce with blades until blood flows; others scald until skin peels away. Though life has yet to depart, their bellies are slit open, bones removed, sinews stripped, intestines torn out, and flesh carved away. The agony they endure is beyond measure, and the karmic retribution they incur is impossible to repay.

They kill sacred birds—phoenixes, cranes, geese, ducks, turtledoves, pigeons, crows, magpies, owls, and kites—along with all manner of flying creatures. They stretch tall nets, raise long poles with sticky paste, pluck feathers and singe wings, or maim them in treetops. Desperate for death yet unable to die, longing for life yet denied it, they sever their feet, remove their heads, cut off their wings, gouge out their eyes, all to fill the kitchen and sate their hunger.

They kill soft-shelled turtles, alligators, tortoises, snails, clams, crabs, and other armored creatures. They drain rivers and dig trenches, set bamboo traps and scatter sand, cast nets and weirs, or use baskets to ensnare scales and fins. They boil and butcher them on islands, piling bones into mountains, their stench carried on the wind. Though they have taken countless lives, their desire remains unquenched.

They kill snakes, vipers, scorpions, bees, wasps, dung beetles, midges, centipedes, locusts, ants, and all manner of crawling things. They kill mosquitoes, horseflies, lice, fleas, mayflies, moths, and other creatures born of transformation—every wriggling, flying, or submerged being.

Though these may be venomous creatures, they too seek peace. They thrive in heat and dampness, perish in cold and ice, all partaking in the transformations of creation, never entering the kitchen. To kill them without cause—how can such suffering be endured?

They fly hawks and hunt with dogs, draw bows and nock arrows, their hearts stirred by greed and savagery, knowing only the taking of life. They set mountains ablaze, drain forests and rivers dry. They wield arrows and blades, grasp spears and halberds, killing living beings. They crush with hands, trample with feet, press down while sitting or lying, killing living beings. They till fields and plant crops, build walls and erect barriers, killing living beings. They construct houses, dig pits, and excavate earth, killing living beings. They dismantle fences, clear grass, and level ground, killing living beings. They gather firewood, fell trees, pluck flowers, and pull up grass, killing living beings. They light lamps and raise candles, killing living beings. They divert water into burrows or pour boiling water on the ground, killing living beings. They wash their hair, bathe their bodies, drink water, and eat meals, killing living beings. They thresh grain and husk wheat, split open wombs and crush eggs, killing living beings. They swat ropes, fan away mosquitoes, open their mouths, close their eyes, raise their hands, or stamp their feet, killing living beings. They kill before sacred images, scriptures, or in the presence of the Dharma; they carry creatures home from the ritual arena to slaughter. In anger or frustration, without cause, they kill living beings. In joy or revelry, indulging their desires, they kill living beings. They slaughter for sacrifices to ghosts and spirits, or for the sick, seeking to avert unseen misfortune. They prepare medicinal decoctions using living creatures, killing them. Some die in their hands, others perish on the butcher’s block, roasted in raging fires, their lineages severed, their reproduction halted, their life roots destroyed, utterly annihilated.

They kill creditors, enemies, or good people from the four directions. They abort fetuses and crush eggs, not sparing even birds and beasts. They kill out of fear, out of dread, by their own hand, or by instructing others. They kill through cursing, poisoning, or drugging. They kill through spells, anger, or joy. They kill deliberately, accidentally, with words, hands, intent, thoughts, glances, or in combat.

In all such acts of killing, with every movement of hand or body, they cruelly harm all manner of creatures. Each bears its own sin, and none can escape retribution.

Thus speaks the Compassionate Honored One:
He who amasses boundless wealth will surely bring suffering upon himself;
He who accumulates excess sin will repay his past debts.
Without remorse, without a heart to save, he remains mired in delusion.
Calamity flows to his ancestors, and upon death, he enters the hells of interrogation and punishment, enduring every torment.
Even if he is reborn, his form will be that of a different species.
Without repentance, how can he transcend this fate?

Then the Compassionate Honored One proclaimed again in lamentation:
In past lives, you killed living beings—
Cattle, sheep, pigs, chickens, dogs,
Geese, ducks, pheasants, rabbits,
Deer, tigers, leopards, and their kin,
Owls, crows, swallows, sparrows,
Jackals, wolves, foxes, raccoon dogs,
Mules, donkeys, horses,
Fish, turtles, cicadas, maggots,
Snails, clams, shrimp, mussels,
Dung beetles, ants, and their like,
Leeches, mosquitoes, fleas, lice,
Centipedes, midges, and all manner of worms.
You slaughtered them all, never awakening a heart of kindness.
Whoever you encountered, you harmed without mercy,
And upon death, you fell into the hells,
Enduring every suffering, tormented day and night.
In that place of unbearable agony,
All those cattle and sheep
Will come to demand their lives,
Saying, “You ate my flesh.”
Or, “You killed my body,”
Claiming you had no right.
Today, we meet again—
You must repay your past debts.

Even as you seek escape, there is no path—
The demon-king unfolds the scroll of transgressions.
Upon examination, the truth is known:
Life for life, each must be repaid.

If reborn in another form,
You enter the assembly of beasts,
Again becoming oxen, sheep, or dogs,
Even geese, ducks, and their kind.
Subjected once more to slaughter,
You repay the sins of your past life.

Today, in this grand repentance hall, all present—
As the sutras declare—
Every sentient being,
For killing without cause,
Or causing others to kill,
Has committed acts swift and innumerable.
To repay life and settle karmic debts,
Who can take another’s place?
In life, one suffers punishment,
Relying on the strength of kinship;
But upon death, entering the Three Wicked Paths,
Who will come to your rescue?

Such karmic retribution is clear and exact.

**Chapter Three: On Not Violating the Fast**

Today, in this Daoist sanctuary, all assembled turn their minds as one, bowing their heads to the Merciful Honored One, repenting the transgressions of breaking the fast.

The repentant one, [Name], gathers the heart, kneels in reverence, and listens attentively to the scriptural words: All sentient beings, from the moment they receive form until this very day, have been bound by stinginess, greed, and craving—drinking wine, eating meat, chewing without restraint, nourishing flesh and blood, fostering pus and decay. Day by day, afflictions and illnesses arise, and the roots of sin grow ever deeper.

Moreover, through birth, aging, sickness, and death, through scorching heat, dampness, cold, and wind, through bitter pain and corrosive suffering, they are assailed by noxious qi, and a hundred diseases invade the body. Thought after thought, impermanence ceaselessly presses on, day and night unrelenting. The bodily form and the knowing nature differ in each, yet all revolve in endless cycles, trapped for ten thousand kalpas without escape.

These sentient beings, their minds often corrupted, treat the fasts and precepts with irreverence. As the years advance and old age approaches, as sickness and distress entwine them, in this one life, one lifetime, they toil for self-preservation, all because of their voracious consumption of impure foods. Their organs steam and ferment, offending the true and sacred ones. The winds of karma fan their bodies, causing gold and jade to dissolve, their forms to wither prematurely.

Yet I, who neither drink nor eat, embrace the Dao in its naturalness, transforming without limit, living forever without death. I constantly expound the scriptures and teachings, seeking to deliver all beings. If, in their ignorance and delusion, they cannot believe or follow, I am ever concerned, never at rest. Thus, I offer the fast as a means to dispel their sickness and suffering.

Moreover, the hosts of the Three Clarities, who long ago realized the truth of the Dao, always observe the fasts with diligence, never growing lax. How much more so the six fasts of the lunar months, the ten days of upright conduct, the eight seasonal nodes, the three primal festivals, the jiazi and benming days, the three assemblies of the gengshen, and all other fasts and gatherings—subtle and wondrous beyond thought—all established by the Merciful Honored One to guide and receive sentient beings, enabling them to cultivate practice and escape the perils of demonic obstacles.

Yet you, all you sentient beings, though you know the names of these fasts, do not arouse reverent hearts. And even when you do, you often violate them. Some mix impure foods, blending the foul with the sacred, sharing the same kitchen without purifying themselves, treating all with careless disdain. Others eat after midday, their minds still stained, slandering the utmost truth, equating it with falsehood. Their words are deceitful, their hearts swayed by love and hatred. Such foolishness leads to countless violations of the fast.

Some break the Fast of the Great Perfected, some the Fast of the Golden Register, some the Fast of Divine Incantations, some the Fast of the Yellow Register, some the Fast of Illuminating the True, some the Fast of Spontaneous Perfection, some the Three Primal Fasts, some the Fast of Mud and Ash, some the Fast of the Cavern Spirits—fasts such as these, whether established for the state, for the deliverance of ancestors, for the rescue of the drowning, for the sake of departed kin, or for the benefit of others. At first, they arise with faith and devotion, but later, regret takes hold. Their sins deepen, and they suffer boundless torment.

If, for the sake of the Dharma-body of ordained men and women, whether ten, a hundred, or even more, the fast is distributed according to its scale, ensuring no partiality, then all who speak of fasting must do so with a giving heart—not with ostentation, nor with meager offerings. Those who are ordained should share equally in the fast. To select or discriminate is to treat it with disdain. To fail to arouse reverence is to break the fast.

Furthermore, if one takes for oneself even a single coin from the offerings of a fast, the construction of images, or any other materials, one must repay tenfold within ten years. If not repaid, the retribution is severe illness, deformity, and eternal banishment from the human realm. They will roost like birds, sleep exposed like beasts. Even if reborn as humans, they will be afflicted by the six chronic illnesses—deaf, blind, and lacking the five senses. If one uses the food of the fast to make offerings to the Dharma-body, or the banners and canopies for venerable images, yet does so without reverence, later growing remorseful, the karmic consequences are beyond description.

When life ends, they are reborn as hungry ghosts—necks thin as bowstrings, bellies swollen like drums, bodies burdened by iron wheels, flames scorching them on all sides. To cover themselves with cloth is like touching a mountain of fire. When they eat or drink, it turns to pus and blood. If they suffer this in the present life, they lie bedridden with malignant disease, their bodies festering and foul, shunned by all. For years and months, flesh wastes away, sinews dissolve. Once cast into hell, they will scarcely be reborn in heaven. In future lives, even if born among humans, they will be deaf, blind, and afflicted by the six illnesses, bereft of beauty, inferior to others. All their kin will treat them as outcasts. If they become husband and wife, they will part midway, leaving orphaned sons and widowed daughters to depend on others. Poor, cold, and hungry, their forms will be ugly, barely clinging to human form.

All such sins arise from breaking the fast. If one does not repent, they will sink ever deeper. Thus, the Merciful Honored One, for the sake of those yet unawakened, speaks these verses:

Those who break the fast in life
Are reborn as hungry ghosts.
Hungry, they eat raging fire;
Thirsty, they drink molten bronze.
Their bodies char and wither,
Treading the edge of frost and blade.
Day and night without respite,
Their suffering knows no end.
Even if a time of liberation comes,
They are no better than dogs and horses—
Hungry, cold, poor, and lowly,
How could they possess full form?

I now extend my compassion,
My wisdom boundless through kalpas.
I establish this great Dharma-bridge
To save the foolish and deaf.
I bow my head to the Supreme Dao,
Roaming freely in the Palace of the Great Ultimate.

**Chapter One: Dispelling Disobedience and Rebellion**

Today, the great assembly of this ritual arena, each turning their minds, bow their heads to the Merciful Honored One, repenting the sins of disobedience and unfilial impiety.

The repentance master, so-and-so, gathers their mind, kneels reverently, and listens attentively to the scriptural words. All sentient beings, from the moment they receive the illumination of sun and moon, drift with the turning of fate, endowed with skin and hair, all owing to their parents.

The Universal Savior says: Without examining the causes and conditions of parents, the weight of their kindness and obligation, how can one know the requital of their nurturing?

The Merciful Honored One says:
If the form is straight, its shadow must be upright;
If the form is not straight, its shadow must be crooked.
If the voice is clear, its echo must be pure;
If the voice is not clear, its sound must be turbid.
Filial piety and impiety follow this principle.

If one is filial and fraternal, within a single household, the old and young live in peace. The world holds them in esteem, divine spirits guard them, and descendants carry on the lineage, their filial kindness unbroken. They attract filial devotion, treasuring it as a precious jewel.

Yet if one is unfilial, generation after generation, within a single household, all become enemies. Though they speak of parents, they treat them as foes, summoning the disobedient to be their children. Parents and siblings keep separate finances and meals, share gardens but divide vegetables, split fields and grain, hide delicacies, and eat in secret. Though in human form, they are worse than birds and beasts. Divine spirits do not protect them; all their deeds in life are inauspicious. Upon death, they enter hell, enduring every suffering. Only after ten thousand kalpas are they reborn, as the *bailao* bird, whose young, upon hatching, devour their mother. Only after leaving the nest do they return to the human realm, where the unfilial gather as fathers and sons, harming one another, mutually resentful. No suffering in the world exceeds this.

Yet without a father, one would not be born; without a mother, one would not be raised. Thus, heaven and earth cover and nurture, entrusting life to the mother’s body. The two *qi* congeal, and for ten months she carries the child, burdened and heavy, sitting and lying uncomfortably. When the time is full, at the moment of birth, the mother is terrified, her life hanging by a thread. Her heart aches, her spirit grieves, and in an instant, she fears for her life. On the day of delivery, internal and external pains assail her, agony intertwined. She loses her voice in wailing, enduring great torment, trembling in fear, shocked and sighing.

Once born, the mother rejoices beyond measure, wrapping the child in swaddling clothes. For three months, she lies on her side, ever wary of evil spirits. When hungry, the child needs food—only the mother feeds them. When thirsty, the child needs drink—only the mother nurses them. Calculating the milk she drinks, it amounts to eight *hu* and four *sheng*. For a thousand days, the mother carries the child, washing away dirt and grime, placing them in dry spots while taking the wet, swallowing bitterness and offering sweetness. Without the father, there is no closeness; without the mother, there is no nurturing.

In the *Kaihuang* kalpa of old, there was a sentient being whose parents were aged, their strength and vitality waning. From dawn to dusk, their child never came to inquire after them. The parents dwelled alone in an empty room, like strangers. They had little clothing and scant food, hunger and cold piercing their bodies. Their hands and feet were stiff, their ears deaf and eyes dim. They slept on a single bed with a thin mat, each day feeling like a year. Their bodies were frail and emaciated, infested with ants and lice. Mosquitoes bit their flesh, and they could not sleep all night, sighing and groaning. Seeing their child’s unfilial conduct, they leaned on a staff to call out, heads bowed and breath subdued, wishing to voice their grievances but unable to finish their words. Their child raised their voice, glaring angrily, and cursed their parents. Turning away, they retreated, leaning on the wall to return home, beating their chest in sorrow, eyes swollen from weeping, crying out in misery, wishing they had died sooner.

The mother said to her elder son: When you were small, had I not raised you, fed you, and shielded you, you would not have survived. For ten months, I carried you like a heavy burden, my breath panting, more labored than running. At times, I suffered chills and fever, unable to sit or lie comfortably. My belly split, my chest felt full, my hair fell out, and I grew thin, unable to eat. A month before birth, I was constantly anxious, fearing we would not part. On the day of delivery, my life was like a flickering candle. My limbs and veins felt as if cut by knives, my five viscera and six bowels burned like fire. After you were born, joy and fear mingled; the pains and sorrows cannot be fully described. For three years, I carried you day and night, never apart. I endured filth, lost sleep, and missed meals, watching your complexion to tend to your hunger and fullness. If you fell ill, my heart ached for you. Hearing your suffering, I could not eat. My mouth and throat were parched as I sought every blessing. Gold and silver, clothes and toys—I wished for your safety and spared nothing.

I remember when you were small, you followed me everywhere, never leaving my side. You ate when I ate, slept when I slept. A single day without me, and you would not eat all day; a single night without me, and you would cry without sleep. How have you grown to suddenly become my enemy? Now, though I have you, it would be better if I had never borne you. I wish I could die soon and be free of you.

Thus, that child truly incurred the grave sin of disobedience and unfilial impiety. Upon death, they entered the Fengdu Hell of the North, enduring every suffering, experiencing all bitterness, dying and being reborn ten thousand times—none of it can be fully recounted.

Then, the Merciful Honored One, for those yet unenlightened, spoke this verse:

Good naturally meets good,
Evil returns to its evil root.
In life, lacking kindness and filial piety,
In death, one sinks forever.
Enduring all sufferings,
Passing through the eighteen gates.
If not on the day of my three pardons,
One will never hear of liberation.
Reborn as the *bailao* bird,
Flesh and bone torn by one’s young.
When the retribution is complete and one returns to the human path,
One meets again as child and grandchild.

**Chapter Two: Vowing to Repay the Kindness of Mercy**

Today, in this ritual arena, each member of the great assembly directs their mind and takes refuge in the Merciful Honored One, speaking of the karmic causes and effects of repaying the kindness of mercy. The repentant one, [Name], collects their thoughts, kneels in reverence, and listens attentively to the scriptural words. All beings cycle through birth and death, revolving through the dark realms. Now, I radiate great light, penetrating the five directions and ten lands. All suffering beings are delivered, save only those guilty of disobedience, who cannot ascend. Know that the kindness and righteousness of parents is profound and weighty. The boundless heavens cannot be repaid; even grinding one’s bones to powder and carving one’s flesh cannot fully requite it. If one can cultivate steadfast resolve, outwardly practicing filial devotion and nurturing, inwardly harboring vast compassion, then not only one’s own parents, but all beings are one’s parents. All beings are one’s brothers. All beings are one’s sisters. All beings are one’s flesh and blood. All beings are one’s sons and daughters. All beings are those who nurture and raise. All beings are those one loves and protects. Do not harm their lives; do not consume their flesh. Whether in past lives, future lives, or the present life, regard all beings as kin. Through manifold expedient means, this is called repaying kindness. Should any man or woman wish to perform meritorious deeds to repay the kindness of heaven and earth, the sovereign, their teachers, and their birth parents, let them proceed in order: first for heaven and earth, second for the emperor, third for their teachers, fourth for their birth parents, fifth for all beings of the great earth, and sixth for all their own kin. Yet among worldly men and women, from the moment they emerge from their mother’s womb, through one year, ten years, a hundred years, or a hundred and twenty years, they must prepare in advance. Beginning with the first seven-day period, cycling repeatedly, even unto distant years, let the meritorious deeds they perform follow this order: first, commissioning images; second, commissioning scriptures; third, erecting long banners of forty-nine feet, establishing forty-nine Dharma bodies, providing vegetarian feasts, and constructing ritual arenas to invite scriptures and images. Let the Dharma masters’ ritual lamps number forty-nine vessels, or more as their capacity allows. Let lamps be arranged like chariot wheels, burning for three days and nights, seven days and nights, or forty-nine days and nights, dedicated to the sovereign, the emperor, their teachers, Dharma kin, parents, siblings, and all their own kin. With hearts laid bare and utmost sincerity, they pay homage to my invoked titles, repent their own transgressions, pray for blessings and grace, repay the kindness of mercy, offer wholehearted devotion, and extol with praise.

All past transgressions, once repented, must be amended with renewed cultivation. Diligently observe fasts and precepts, turn the heart toward compassion and goodness, and extend almsgiving to the fields of merit—whether to the poor and lowly, the disabled, the sick and solitary elders, prisoners, hungry ghosts, or all sentient beings. Those who lack benevolence should be exhorted to embrace virtuous causes. For travelers from afar in dire need, provide succor, rescue them from peril, and offer clothing and food to ensure their sufficiency. Then, renew the vow to honor parents with filial piety. The wealthy should commission images and copy scriptures to deliver beings from the three wretched destinies and the five sufferings, and to liberate those sunk in the depths of torment. According to their vows, they may attain rebirth—this is the repayment of kindness.

If any man or woman, through accumulated deeds, has ever slandered the Three Treasures, been disloyal or unfilial, offended the sovereign or ruler, teachers, or parents, or committed the five grave transgressions—such deep and weighty sins that they fear falling into hell at life’s end and suffering myriad torments—let them, for the sake of the sovereign, ruler, teachers, or parents, generate resolve and make vows: transcribe scriptures and repentance texts, even a single line or verse; venerate my invoked titles, one or two or many. On the day of their passing, they shall not enter hell nor endure former karmic retribution, but proceed directly to heaven to receive boundless joy.

If any man or woman, for the sake of the sovereign, ruler, teachers, parents, or their own kin, observes the Three Primes and Eight Festivals, either at home or at sacred altars, venerates my sacred titles, repents sins and averts misfortune, holds grand vegetarian feasts, prepares fragrant offerings piled high as mountains, gathers fruits and herbs, presents flowers, and arranges pure offerings—vigilantly seeking blessings and grace through the night—then may the nation and household be secured, the great earth delivered, and all sentient beings rescued. Let none commit the ten evils or grave offenses, and may the sins of nine generations of ancestors, whether already suffered or yet to be, all be extinguished. If on such days the meaning of the scriptures is expounded, and the ignorant and benighted are guided to awaken loyalty, filial piety, and the resolve to save others, this merit shall be foremost.

Then, the Compassionate Honored One, for the sake of those yet unawakened, spoke this verse:

All people in the world,
Should cultivate filial piety in body and mind.
Revere and cherish heaven and earth,
As you would your own parents.
Ultimately attain the fruit of the Dao,
With wondrous practices renewed each day.
I now expound the sublime Dharma,
To deliver those sunk in suffering.
Karma unfolds in endless retribution,
Turning the wheel of kalpas day and night.
I establish this great Dharma bridge,
To ferry you across the river of craving.
Wondrous indeed are the Three Caverns’ scriptures,
Transcending those with karmic affinity.

Today, the great assembly of this Dao altar, each with focused mind, reverently faces the Compassionate Honored One to repent and release the multitude of residual karmic obstructions. The repentance master, with sincere heart and kneeling posture, listens attentively to the scriptural words:

All beings arise from the primordial qi of the undifferentiated. Through the kindness of parents—carrying, nurturing, breastfeeding—they gradually grow, yet unable to discern, they become entangled in desire, and the roots of transgression flourish. If not for repentance, if not for the expounding of scriptures and precepts, gently guiding them into the right Dao, they would forever remain bound by the ignorance of aversion and attachment, fettered to the mundane world.

Parents can only give birth to us; they cannot perfect us. It is our teachers who reveal the scriptures and precepts, enabling us to transcend afflictions. Thus, the kindness of teachers surpasses even that of parents.

Yet we see beings who, from the moment they establish themselves in the world, fail to recognize the profound debt owed to their teachers. Instead, they respond with scorn and abuse, withhold what is needed, deny sweet sustenance, refuse clothing and food, treat them as strangers, or even plot harm. Such acts align them with rebellious children, inviting karmic retribution in return.

We see beings who observe fasts and precepts—some, occupying high positions, humiliate those beneath them; others, relying on wealth and status, oppress the orphaned and impoverished...

Some abuse their power to oppress the lowly and weak; others, holding office, make extortion their intent, inflicting cruel punishments at will, enriching themselves at public expense, and acting against the Dao/Way. They encroach upon the blessed lands of the Three Treasures, occupying their pure sanctuaries. Some commission revered images, transcribe scriptures, or establish sacred observatories, construct refectories, and hold fasts and rituals. Yet as leaders, they steal property, engage in fraudulent trade, or misappropriate the wealth of monastic endowments or donors. They live alongside parents, siblings, and kin, yet in all their dealings, they deceive and rob one another. They shift fences to encroach on others’ land, seize fields and gardens, exploit public authority to seize others’ inns and shops, cheat merchants in trade, use false weights and measures, reduce lengths and widths, conceal fractions of grain, falsify calculations, substitute coarse for fine, exchange short for long, and devise a hundred deceits to gain the slightest profit. They burn others’ homes, falsely implicate the innocent, envy others’ wealth and status, spread slander, and vent rage upon their parents. They lend capital to exact exorbitant interest, indulge in greed and desire, seize others’ property by force, refuse to repay debts, and deny their obligations. They kill without cause, engage in illicit sacrifices, defy public and private authority, file baseless accusations, act with arrogance and rudeness, deceive superiors and betray subordinates. Some strip the belongings of ordained practitioners, desecrate graves to steal coffins, or cast nets and traps to cunningly seize creatures from ponds, pools, rivers, the Huai and Ji, seas and streams, springs, lakes, and waterways. Such karmic offenses are manifold and beyond count. If beings commit even one such transgression, they incur grave retribution, burdening billions of ancestors across ten thousand generations, as well as their parents, themselves, and their six relations and nine clans. The deceased and those of past lives suffer misfortune, descending into hell, where each is ground by millstones, enduring retribution for ten thousand kalpas before rebirth—if reborn at all, they may not survive infancy, living out their days in solitude. Such karmic conditions are predestined. Today, in this ritual assembly, as the scriptures declare, the sins and blessings, good and evil of beings return in retribution, seen and heard like a turning wheel, swift as an echo. Let each gather their thoughts and cultivate in accord with the teachings. If years pass in vain, and age and illness press upon you, when body and life perish in a single day, what means remain to escape this sinking into darkness? Through this rite of repentance, may all—those present, past, and yet to incur such karmic offenses—receive the moisture of the Dharma, universally attain liberation, and be freed from bondage.

Those who are mute and unable to speak have come from slandering the Dharma-body of the renunciates.

**First Chapter: Deliverance from the Sufferings of Fengdu Hell**

Today, the great assembly of this *Dao* altar, each with concentrated mind, reverently faces the Compassionate Honored One to deliver those suffering in Fengdu Hell.

The repentant master, kneeling in prostration, listens attentively to the scriptural words: Hell is neither existent nor nonexistent.

The Universal Savior asks, “Why is it said to be nonexistent?”
The Compassionate Honored One replies, “If all sentient beings do not indulge the three karmic actions, do not give rein to the six senses, do not commit the ten evils, nor perpetrate the five rebellious acts or any transgressions, then upon death they will not enter the nine dark hells of Fengdu but proceed directly to the heavenly realms, carefree and at ease. This is what is meant by nonexistent.”

“Why is it said to be not nonexistent?”
“If sentient beings indulge the three karmic actions and six senses, commit the ten evils, the five rebellious acts, and boundless transgressions, then upon death they will enter the nine dark hells of Fengdu, where each offense is examined and punished. They shall endure bitter agonies for ten thousand kalpas before rebirth. This is what is meant by not nonexistent.”

Since it is known to be not nonexistent, one must seek repentance. A single day of self-reflection, awakening, and repentance dissolves the sins of ten thousand kalpas. How is the power of this repentance known? In ancient times, there was a man born foolish and ignorant, who committed myriad sins. One day, he reflected and awakened; witnessing the five signs of decay, he was seized with terror and took refuge in the Three Treasures. Thereupon, the roots of his decay and transgressions instantly dissolved, and his heavenly years were prolonged. Thus, all here present, with the teachings clearly expounded, know that repentance enables sentient beings to avoid hell and its manifold sufferings.

If one does not encounter a good spiritual guide, evil karma deepens. They may know only to wash away the grease and grime from the body but fail to sweep the dust from the heart. Thus, at life’s end, they enter hell and endure the weight of their transgressions. At such a time, remorse and fear come too late. Body and mind are shattered, spirit and soul scattered. The wind-knives stand before them; repentance is no longer possible. What recourse remains for their suffering?

All you sentient beings, do not rely on your prime of life, do not cling to wealth and treasure, do not become attached to family and kin. Do not indulge in fleeting pleasures, courting the agony of death. When the great limit arrives, it spares neither rich nor poor, neither old nor young, neither noble nor base—all are ground to nothingness. Like the wind’s lamp or spark from stone, what endures? Like lightning at noon or morning dew, what is firm?

When the five celestial messengers and the death-dealing ghosts of impermanence arrive, even youth and radiant beauty cannot resist. At that moment, grand halls and secluded chambers become irrelevant; fine carriages and mighty steeds cannot follow; wives, children, and kin are no longer one’s own; the seven treasures and precious ornaments become playthings for others. The Merciful Honored One said: In the Red Clarity Kalpa of old, there was a sentient being, sharp-witted and intelligent, who subdued afflictions. Though wealthy, he refused to give alms to the poor. When his life ended, he fell into the animal realm, reborn as a red fox, enduring karmic retribution in full. All you sentient beings, be ever vigilant—lest in a single morning you be bound to such suffering, when regret comes too late.

Consider this: in the world of the living, if one faces even a minor matter and must enter the public court, though the offense be slight, the heart trembles in fear. Kinfolk grow anxious, exhausting every means to seek deliverance. How much more so for the beings in hell? Compared to them, such distress is but a shadow.

Countless hells, numbering in the hundreds of thousands, are all governed within this celestial realm. Located in the far north, beyond the Northern Heavens, past boundless, measureless dark abysses, there lies a world called the Five Qi Mystic Heaven, the Dark North, the Solitary, Profound, and Utmost Land. Within it, the Five Qi Five Spirits Mystic Elder Black Emperor Heavenly Lord presides over the northern quarter, restraining the yin demons.

Beneath this land lies the Great Void, the Vast Wilderness, and the boundless, fathomless Black Sea. Its waters are vile, its shores unknowable. At its center rises a great mountain, piercing the azure heavens above and plunging into the windy springs below—Mount Fengdu of the North. It towers one million six hundred thousand *li* high, with a circumference of five hundred thousand *li*. Its base sinks fifteen thousand *li* into the water. At the water’s edge, where the mountain’s foot meets the sea, lies a vast cavern called the Yin Shadow Heaven, the land known as Great Yin.

Beneath the Water Emperor are thirty-six lesser hells, each walled in iron, ninefold encircled. Within each hell, grasses and trees arise from the naturally venomous qi, their branches and leaves transformed into blades and swords, their edges sharp and plentiful. Fierce beasts, scorching smoke, and black winds rage ceaselessly, day and night. The darkness is profound, poisonous qi and bloody light surge, and the stench of filth and decay fills the air. The light of sun, moon, and stars cannot penetrate these hells.

Thirty-seven kings preside, each over one hell. Within each, seventy tiers of knife-forests stand, along with countless iron nets. Fire blazes from above, flames surge from below, intertwining like fish in a searing pan. The iron-walled cities have four gates, and at each gate stand four great bronze dogs, each body spanning forty *li*. When they roar, the iron walls tremble. Their fangs are like forests of swords, their claws sharp and forms ferocious—beyond compare.

There are also countless iron birds, each over a *zhang* in size, with beaks of bronze and claws of iron. The Universal Savior speaks: “To the east, west, south, and north, thirty-six hells in all—may we hear their names.”

These thirty-six hells, each governed by the karmic deeds of beings, administer punishment according to their offenses.

At their center lies one hell, where those guilty of the ten evils and five heinous crimes are confined. Within it stand:
Knife Mountains and Sword Trees,
Cauldrons of Boiling Water and Furnaces of Burning Coals,
Molten Copper Pillars,
Iron Plows and Iron Pellets,
Iron Awls and Iron Mills,
Iron Pestles and Iron Mountains,
Iron Nails and Iron Cangues,

Iron Locks and Iron Caskets,
Iron Birds and Ash Rivers,
Snow Mountains and Ice Wells,
Fire Pits and Dismemberment,
Strangulation and Sawing,
Flaying of Skin,
Stinking Turtles and Smoldering Embers,
Burning from Feet to Hands,
Blades, Needles, and Narrow Rocks,
Fire Mountains and Fire Mills—
countless torments, beyond numbering.

Within hangs a mirror that reflects the sins of the damned, revealing every hidden transgression. A moment there is like an eon passed. Ten thousand deaths and ten thousand rebirths, each agony more bitter than the last. No other hell compares.

The warden of this hell oversees all others, hence it is called the Great Central Hell.
*Avīci* means “great,” and *bi* means “to obstruct.” *Wu jian* means “without respite.” Thus, it is called the Great Avīci Hell of Uninterrupted Suffering.
Alternatively, *a* means “unceasing,” and *bi* means “unrelenting.” Torment and pain know no pause, no rest. Within, karmic winds blow upon the bodies and minds of the damned, shattering them into ten thousand deaths, only to revive them in an instant. Thus, in a single moment, ten thousand deaths and ten thousand rebirths occur—so it is in all the hells.

Here, the Great Emperor of Fengdu commands two hundred forty bureaus, overseeing fifty thousand minions who interrogate the damned, probing the weight of their sins, leaving no detail unexamined, and reporting all deeds, good and evil.

Consider the Iron Chariot, engulfed in fierce flames, ever ablaze. A yakṣa dwells within; from afar, the damned see it as a fair maiden and long to approach. Yet upon entering, their flesh and bones turn to ash and smoke.

The Iron Ox’s body, head, fur, horns, and tail are sharp as blades. From afar, the damned see it as a golden lotus, but upon reaching it, flames and smoke consume their bodies, leaving no trace.

The Iron Horse’s form, mane, and tail are keen as sword edges. The Iron Donkey is the same. Each is led by a yakṣa to the damned. When they mount, their bodies dissolve. The Iron Rakes and other implements of torment—cruel, vicious, and venomous, with raging fires and razor edges—are beyond description.

You, all beings, may hear of these torments but must never witness them. Should you encounter such a place, escape would be impossible for ten thousand kalpas.

Do not speak idly of hells and heavens. The unseen and the seen are equal; life and death are the same. It is like a man’s dream and his waking: death is as the dream, and birth as waking. What is done in dreams differs not from waking; what is done in death differs not from life. Joy in dreams is self-made; suffering in waking is self-caused.

You, all beings, should reflect deeply and seek early deliverance. The means to deliverance is none other than repentance. After repentance, abandon past wrongs and cultivate anew.

Moreover, in the Middle Kingdom, it is rare to obtain a human body. Rarer still is one who cultivates good fruits. Like the sun and moon, whose light shines impartially, illuminating all, leaving no darkness unlit—you, all beings, are neither blind nor deaf. The blind see not the sun and moon; the deaf hear not of good and evil. Having heard of good and evil, having seen the sun and moon, those who do not awaken are like vines clinging to a tree: as the tree grows, so do they. When the tree falls, what will the vines cling to?

Today, the assembly of this Daoist sanctuary, as the scriptures warn, trembles in fear and sorrow. Now, with diligence, we bow in repentance, seeking mercy. May we, life after life, never encounter such places. May all beings in hells, hungry ghosts, and animal realms alike attain liberation.

Their five bodily parts are boiled and simmered, their four limbs fester and dissolve, pus and blood reek with foulness—unbearable torment. For ten thousand kalpas, they suffer without respite, day and night.

Pǔjì asked, “What grave offenses condemn one to such torment? And who presides over their unceasing interrogation?”

The Compassionate One replied, “Those who commit the three karmic transgressions—slandering the Great Vehicle, disloyalty to the sovereign, maligning monastics, defiling the Dharma-body, destroying sacred images, or embezzling monastic property—fall into the Nine Dark Hells to endure this retribution. Pǔjì asked, “Is each transgression met with a single punishment, or are a hundred offenses met with a hundred torments?”

The Compassionate One replied, “Iron beds and bronze pillars, agony unbearable—crushed bones and scorched sinews repay the sin of lust. Freezing cold that sears to the bone, forcing them to lie in icy rivers, repays the sin of theft. Molten copper poured into their mouths, tongues torn out and plowed, eyes pecked by vile birds. Sword trees splay their limbs, grinding mills pulverize them like grain—this repays the sin of deceitful glances. Their bodies become hungry ghosts, wandering through cauldrons of boiling liquid, forced to swallow iron pellets when hunger strikes—this repays the sin of breaking precepts. Each interrogation and torment corresponds precisely to their karma, with no discrepancy.

**Section Five: Liberation from Harm Caused by Womb-Birth**

Today, within this sacred precinct, all assembled turn their minds in devotion, prostrating before the Supreme Numinous Treasure’s Compassionate Savior of Suffering in the ten directions, to dissolve and release the calamities of womb-birth and harm inflicted upon others.

The repentant patron [Name], gathering their heart in reverence, kneels and listens attentively, invoking this aspiration:

For the harm of womb-birth is inherited across generations—ancestral customs of worshipping ghosts and spirits, immersion in worldly defilements, and the proliferation of deceit and transgression. Thus, sins accumulate like mountains, summoning severe retribution. In recent years, affairs have been fraught with misfortune, entangled in illness and suffering, with unceasing calamities. Frightening dreams arise in profusion, and strange omens manifest without end. Since ancient times, the afflictions of ancestors have never ceased.

Whether from the three generations of great-grandparents, seven generations of ancestors, nine lineages of kin, or the three lifetimes of parents—both maternal and paternal—if ancestral tombs remain unsettled, they may harbor litigious spirits or malevolent ghosts, their baleful influence unbroken. Or perhaps in burial, construction, relocation, or renovation; in marriage rites or the selection of inauspicious days and hours; in violating taboos; or in excavating pits and trenches, disturbing earth spirits—such acts may subject the living and the dead to torment and punishment, binding their souls in confinement. **First Chapter: Praying for the State**

Today, the assembly of this Daoist ritual, each with focused mind, gazes reverently toward the Compassionate Honored One. May you expound for all beings, teaching them to pray for the state and their households, seeking grace and blessings.

The repentant patron [Name], kneeling with hands clasped, listens attentively to the scriptural words. If the sovereign faces calamity—celestial bodies losing their course, wars erupting on all sides, winds and rains unbalanced, the hundred grains failing to ripen, the people stricken by plague, the land unsettled, armies mobilized for campaigns, or any manner of disasters and inauspicious omens—all must be reported to me.

Great merits shall be cultivated: transcribing scriptures and commissioning sacred images, establishing temples to deliver beings, and offering from the treasury precious treasures, jewels, gold, silver, pearls, coral, amber, palace gardens, silken banners, fields, gardens, and dwellings. These shall be dedicated as alms, sown into the field of the Three Treasures, to deliver sentient beings, rescue those in peril, release prisoners, establish fasts and precepts, arrange hundreds of high seats, and expound the profound and wondrous teachings of the Great Vehicle. Thus shall the people of the realm be exhorted to listen to the Dharma, practice almsgiving and repentance, and accumulate boundless, inconceivable merits of salvation and protection.

If the sovereign and ministers indulge in wrath, pursue depravity, slaughter without restraint, seek self-indulgence, and oppress all beings, bringing forth calamities upon the people—where sun and moon lose their brightness, baleful stars encroach upon the imperial throne, the land suffers floods and droughts, omens and locusts appear, the people rebel, and usurpers rise—then the sovereign and all under heaven must summon the Three Caverns’ Dharma Bodies and the assembly of the altar, countless in number, to fill sacred altars, temples, mountains, waters, grottoes, and holy sites. There, grand rituals shall be established, banners and canopies hung, flowers scattered, incense burned, lamps lit, the Dao practiced day and night, repentance offered without weariness, and the six periods observed with diligence. Treasures shall be widely dispensed to rescue all beings. Then, by my Dao-power, I shall manifest great divine transformations to assist in dispelling these disasters, causing the afflictions to dissolve at once.

If within the realm the Five Stars lose their proper course, dim luminaries stray, the Twenty-Eight Constellations deviate from their domains, sun and moon suffer eclipses, and yin and yang fall out of harmony, then the Southern Director of Destinies, Lord Han the Venerable, and the Controller of the Eight Directions of the Celestial Sphere, Sima the Longevous, shall regulate the celestial mechanism, restoring them to their rightful positions, and all calamitous omens shall be extinguished.

If great drought leaves the people parched and suffering, then the Dragon Kings shall shake thunder and summon torrential rains to end the drought’s hardship. If heavy rains pour unceasingly, floods surge to the heavens, and the people drown, then the Jade Maiden of the River, the Dark Lord of the Nine Seas, and the Officers of the True Qi shall gather the water-qi, part the clouds, and halt the rain, causing the waters to recede without harm. At this time, all dragon-spirits and ghosts shall likewise turn toward goodness.

If external demons, evil spirits, or malevolent ghosts—*chimei* and *wangliang*—enter the land to spread sickness and suffering, they shall be expelled together, allowed no respite. By the weight of my compassion and virtue, the imperial domain shall be eternally secured, the sovereign’s power ever renewed. The people shall ascend to the court of benevolence and longevity, the state placed within the realm of Huaxu. Yin and yang shall harmonize, sun and moon shine eternally, the seas and lands know peace, ministers and people enjoy well-being, the three frontiers remain tranquil, and the five grains flourish abundantly.

Yet, among the people of the world, though their wealth, status, and conditions differ, even if they cultivate the Dao, they may not discern the proper path. They may perform deeds yet remain beset by calamities, wavering in doubt, unable to attain clarity. They wonder: does the merit of salvation and protection vary in degree?

The Compassionate Honored One replied: Salvation and deliverance from distress depend upon utmost sincerity; the almsgiving of wealth is not measured by quantity. There are five kinds of merit:

First, the creation of my sacred images—true, responsive, and transformative manifestations. Blessings shall flow across kalpas, and retribution shall be boundless. Why? Because sentient beings, lost in delusion, cannot fix their minds. Beholding my true form, they generate devotion. With devotion arisen, true numen descends to meet them. Focused and unwavering, they attain the fruit of non-action.

Second, the transcription of scriptural teachings—the Great Vehicle of the Three Caverns. Blessings shall flow eternally, and merits shall be immeasurable. For scriptures guide the deluded, awakening boundless Dao-mind in beings, leading them from confusion to enlightenment, from enlightenment to truth. All sages who cultivate the Dao ascend to its fruition.

Third, the establishment of temples to deliver beings, the construction of halls and sanctuaries. The merit is boundless, inconceivable. Why?

Third, the deliverance of beings through monastic ordination and temple stewardship, the propagation of scriptures and icons to teach and transform sentient beings, inspiring them to awaken the Dao-mind—one realization opening myriad gates. Through the turning of karmic conditions, they aid the nation and transform the people, spreading the Dao and illuminating the Dharma, yielding the greatest benefit.

Fourth, the observance of purification rites and the practice of the Dao, the performance of repentance and the recitation of scriptures, the offering of praise and the burning of incense. The field of merit is boundless. Thus, purification rites cleanse the heart, the Dao enables penetrating insight, the practice of the Dao atones for transgressions, repentance invokes blessings, and the resonance of merit moves the heavens, dispelling calamities and bestowing fortune, upon which both life and death depend.

Fifth, the bestowal of all things in boundless fields of merit. The karmic retribution is towering, its merit profound and deep. Wealth and possessions are the lifeblood of sentient beings, clung to as if one’s own life, yet to relinquish them without hesitation, to give without stinginess, is to broadly establish merit, universally succoring sentient beings, inwardly stilling greed and avarice, outwardly eliminating plunder and theft. In life and death, they receive grace, and both humans and heavens reap the benefit.

These five Dharma-gates of merit-making are to be cultivated gradually according to one’s capacity, safeguarding the nation and securing the household, transcending rebirth and delivering from suffering. As the scriptures say, it is like a single sweet rain—all who receive it are nourished. According to their innate faculties, each attains flourishing growth. So too is the performance of repentance and the seeking of forgiveness.

**Second Scroll: The Salvation of the People**

Today, in this grand Daoist sanctuary, all present turn their minds upward, gazing toward the Merciful Honored One, to broadly save the people and expound all virtuous benefits.

The repentant one, so-and-so, gathers their thoughts, joins their hands, and listens attentively to the scriptural words, ever mindful of sentient beings dwelling in an age of the three poisons and ten evils, beset by specters and malevolent spirits, wicked ghosts and wayward deities, venomous creatures and fierce beasts, blades and warfare, flood and fire, fetters and prisons, sickness and suffering—each affliction clinging fast, leaving none at peace.

Thus are the Three Caverns’ scriptures and precepts expounded, the rites of deliverance and purification performed, to universally ferry all beings across. Talismans, sacred diagrams, and divine incantations are entrusted to those who study the Dao, along with the Heavenly Emperors, the Saviors of Suffering Perfected Ones, the Three Great Demon Kings of Heaven, and the Five Demon Kings of Heaven, who spread throughout the world to rescue and protect all, granting them freedom.

Yet sentient beings, deluded and ignorant, fail to recognize sin and blessing. They indulge the six senses, killing and stealing, engaging in debauchery and dissipation, stinginess and wrath, their natures inverted. They speak deceitfully, utter falsehoods, slander with harsh words and divisive tongues, devour living beings, break fasts and violate precepts, defy heaven and betray earth, turn from the true and embrace the perverse, curse gods and spirits—sins rampant, with not a shred of goodness.

Thus do poisonous winds and malignant qi, the demonic hordes of the Six Heavens, fill the world, spreading slaughter and strife. Those struck down and wounded number in the tens of thousands each day, beyond all reckoning.

The Merciful Honored One dispatches the Heavenly Emperors, the Ten Ultimate Divine Kings, and the Four Administrators of the Three Realms to descend into the human realm, traversing and rescuing, delivering sentient beings, filling heaven and earth—yet who among them knows this?

Now I solemnly declare to you: the methods of salvation are inconceivable, their spiritual responses swift. In universal deliverance, I proclaim with great compassion and mercy, entreating the Honored One to bestow these teachings.

The Merciful Honored One says: On the first day of the year, the eight solar terms, the Three Primes, the dark and full moons, the Five La Days, and the Ten Straight Days—on all such occasions, good men and faithful women who observe these days must abstain from meat and impurity, restrain the six senses, and banish all wayward thoughts. Thus purified, they burn incense, maintain the fast, recite the Dao, and pay homage to my transformed names.

First, they repent for their own transgressions, openly confessing their faults, thereby transferring merit to amend their errors and escape suffering and calamity. If one cannot focus alone, they may invoke the Dharma-bodies of male or female officiants, praying earnestly with devotion, making offerings and prostrations.

Whether at home or in sacred temples, with flowers, fruits, vegetarian meals, banners, blossoms, incense, lamps, and offerings of clothing, bedding, curtains, embroidered mats, fragrant oils, rice, and flour—whatever they possess—then the benevolent spirits will descend at once, delivering them from misfortune.

If one suffers from grave illness, chronic ailments, or the malevolent influence of the Ox Mansion, lingering for years without relief, their vitality drained, their wealth dissipated; if childbirth brings misfortune, or infants perish in their arms; if one leaves the household to become a monastic, only to later regret it; if nightmares and strange visions disturb the mind, or fires and alarms cause terror; if legal troubles arise unjustly, or one violates sacred prohibitions, defies divine retribution, disturbs graves, or is struck by flood, fire, entangling trees, or crushing stones—all manner of calamities, omens, and afflictions—then within the home, perform extensive rites of repentance and supplication. According to one’s means, pay homage to my transformed names, kindle lamps and burn incense day and night without cease. The Four Heavenly Emperor-Kings will descend to protect my transformed names.

The exorcised will be subdued, the sought will be granted, the presented will be conveyed, the entreated will be heeded. Transgressions will be redeemed, the living and the dead will be saved. This form of prayer and exorcism is foremost.

If emperors, kings, great ministers, and royal advisors, along with princes, consorts, imperial children, and celestial descendants, act on behalf of their parents, themselves, their kin, court relatives, and imperial kin, summoning the Dharma-bodies of male and female officiants—regardless of number—to their palaces, where they maintain the fast, practice the Dao, and perform repentance day and night without pause, their devotion unwavering, then the Ten Perfected Ones of Heaven and the Four Administrators and Five Emperors will descend to assess their merits and faults. The sick will recover, the dead will revive, the imperiled will be delivered, the imprisoned will be freed, travelers will return, and officials will be promoted. Water, fire, blades, warfare, tigers, wolves, venomous beasts, malevolent spirits, and spectral entities will never assail them, nor will they suffer harm or offense.

If common folk act on behalf of emperors, kings, the people, the land, and all sentient beings, paying homage to my transformed names and true images, delivering all beings, each will attain peace and bliss—this is most inconceivable.

If warfare erupts on all four fronts, encroaching upon borders, pay homage to my transformed names and true images, and the weapons of war will retreat, leaving no harm or damage.

If plague and pestilence strike the people, and exorcisms bring no relief, pay homage to my transformed names and true images, and the afflicted will recover, free from lingering illness.

If floods and droughts disrupt the seasons, and the five grains fail to ripen, pay homage to my transformed names and true images, and the elements will harmonize, all things flourishing.

If poisonous winds and malignant qi scorch the people, pay homage to my transformed names and true images, and the afflictions will vanish at once, the body and qi restored to tranquility.

If venomous creatures and fierce beasts ravage the people and all living beings, pay homage to my transformed names and true images, and the insects and tigers will flee, the mountain spirits concealing them.

If a woman is pregnant and childbirth brings peril, pay homage to my transformed names and true images, and mother and child will be reunited, free from danger.

Ten thousand disasters will vanish, a thousand transformations and myriad changes will cease. Turn to me, to my transformed names, who broadly protect all sentient beings—no wish will go unfulfilled. With sincere devotion, no peril will remain unaverted.

Today, in this grand Daoist sanctuary, all present must turn their minds as the scriptures instruct, with utmost devotion, paying homage to all transformed names and manifestations.

**Chapter Three: Unbinding the Knots of Sentient Beings**

Today, within this sacred precinct, all assembled turn their minds in reverence toward the Merciful Honored One, the Boundless Dao, and all true sages, that for the sake of sentient beings, they may untie all knots and fetters.

The repentant sponsor, so-and-so, with purified body and mind, bows in profound devotion. As the scriptures declare: In the beginning, the Primordial One transformed the Three Realms with a single qi. Heaven and earth move, and the myriad things take form; humanity dwells within, receiving its nature and nurturing its form, all born of this transformation. Externally, it draws upon refined qi; internally and externally, the five virtues intermingle to take shape. Sentient beings, enveloped within, emerge from the womb after ten months, encircled by the ten qi. As qi circulates and gives life, the hundred joints unfold. Within each joint, qi forms ten knots, and within each knot resides a spirit. Habitual patterns intertwine, and transgressions coil into bonds.

To untie these knots and harmonize the hundred spirits, the ten directions are established, each bearing countless names. Each invoked name has the power to unbind the knots of sentient beings. If the knots of sentient beings are dissolved, they deeply awaken to the source of the Dao—much like in the worldly realm, where capturing a thief requires summoning a thousand soldiers, yet once the thief is seized, not a single soldier is needed.

Moreover, the body of sentient beings is a temporary convergence of earth, water, fire, and wind, of yin and yang, manifest and hidden, all arising from the mutual contamination of the five viscera and six senses. The mind-king and the will-steed sow and cultivate: knots of doubt and delusion, knots of entanglement and obstruction, knots of injury and harm, knots of illness and affliction, knots of slander and strife, knots of enmity and grievance, knots of chronic ailment, knots of muteness and silence, knots of frivolity and play, knots of trade and exchange, knots of wine and gluttony, knots of killing and harm, knots of scalding and fire, knots of jealousy and envy, knots of false speech, knots of frivolity and disdain, knots of greed and desire, knots of reckless bravery, knots of breaking fasts, knots of violating precepts, knots of idle amusement, knots of mental exhaustion, knots of accumulated resentment, knots of shamelessness, knots of lust and desire, knots of deafness, knots of blindness, knots of mental confusion, knots of anger and rage, knots of heavenly nets, knots of earthly snares, knots of water and fire, knots of the bridal chamber, knots of mutual conflict, knots of mutual hindrance.

All such sentient beings, dwelling within heaven and earth, experience the flourishing and withering of form. The burning house seethes unceasingly; floating life is ever restless. With all these vexing knots obstructing and tormenting the fleshly body, knot upon knot intertwines without end.

Pǔjì inquired: What is meant by the mind-king and the will-steed?

The Merciful Honored One replied: The mind is like a sovereign king; the will is like a monkey or a horse—difficult to tame, difficult to subdue, ever-shifting and unceasing. Even if the monkey and horse are stilled, the mind-king does not rest. If one skillfully subdues the sovereign king, the will-steed cannot shift and turn. Once shifting and turning cease, karmic knots no longer arise.

Pǔjì inquired: By what virtuous power may sentient beings be taught to awaken and dissolve these knots?

The Merciful Honored One replied: If sentient beings seek awakening and dissolution, let them, in a place of purity, adorn and purify their homes. According to their means, whether abundant or modest, let them light incense and lamps before my image, venerate the transformed names, repent of grievances and knots, listen attentively, contemplate deeply, and advance with courage and diligence. Thus may they awaken and dissolve all knots, avoiding the depths of suffering.

By the power of this repentance, let there descend the hundredfold-refined vajra, the thousandfold-blended jade elixir, the flowing light of Venus, the dispersed radiance of primal yellow. Let these wash away lewdness and perversity, dissolve grievances and knots, dispel vexation and torment, pacify body and mind. Let goodness and evil naturally align, and malevolence be ground away. May the Four Brahma Perfected Ones and the transformative lords of the ten directions enable all sentient beings to awaken. Let evil karma not arise, and let goodness deepen, that they may attain rebirth—how could they not be delivered?

Furthermore, if sentient beings skillfully dissolve even a single knot, a hundred knots will loosen. They will ascend in pure qi and descend with heavenly talismans. The fierce generals Axiū, Iron-Forehead, and Copper-Headed Dharma-Protecting Divine Kings, with jade hooks and golden locks, will instantly still the thousand knots and myriad resentments, quieting the mind-monkey. Like an orange or a pearl, the will’s knots will forever cease. The mind will be without mind, and knots without knots. Enmity and hatred will be resolved, nets and snares dissolved.

May all sentient beings forever awaken to the true Dao and attain liberation.

Today, within this sacred precinct, all assembled turn their minds to listen attentively, as the scriptures declare: Sentient beings in the world are forever bound by the cage of affliction, with no means of escape—where can they flee? By venerating this repentance ritual, they may suddenly awaken from their entanglements. Now, let them contemplate deeply and advance in reverent devotion.

May the power of virtue extend to all sentient beings, that all the knots they bear may, by the power of repentance, awaken to non-action and ascend to the true Dao.

**Chapter One: Manifesting Merit and Receiving Blessings**

Today, the great assembly of this Dao ritual, each directing their mind, respectfully addresses the Merciful Honored One, declaring their merits to receive blessings. The repentance master, so-and-so, joins palms, kneels, and listens attentively to the scriptural teachings.

The Universal Salvation inquires: The various Dharma gates of merit manifested by the Merciful Honored One exhort and instruct sentient beings to cultivate practice. Yet beings are weak and feeble, unable to fully accomplish these; we wonder what levels of merit may be attained through cultivation.

The Merciful Honored One says: Merit is boundless, but broadly speaking, there are nine types, each yielding blessings according to one’s capacity. All beings should listen carefully:

1. Creating images
2. Copying scriptures
3. Establishing temples
4. Liberating beings
5. Conducting Dao rituals
6. Reciting scriptures and performing repentance rites
7. Upholding precepts
8. Universally offering vegetarian feasts and provisions
9. Practicing generosity

Whether constructing halls, pavilions, towers, galleries, permanent estates, banners, flowers, lamps, candles, bells, chimes, cymbals, or other ritual implements—all such endeavors accumulate boundless merit, bringing immeasurable blessings in the past, present, and future, beyond conception.

Those who create images or copy scriptures will, in this life, attain noble status and, in past lives, be reborn in the families of heavenly kings. Those who establish temples and liberate beings will, in this life, attain great wealth and, in past lives, be reborn in the families of kings. Those who perform rituals and recite invocations will, in this life, be protected by benevolent spirits and, in past lives, be reborn with keen intelligence. Those who uphold vegetarian precepts, revere the teachings, and burn incense will, in this life, enjoy enduring peace and, in past lives, be reborn in wealthy and noble families. Those who observe precepts and repent will, in this life, be revered and protected by the gods and, in past lives, be reborn among humans with perfect form and appearance. Those who offer scriptures and images will, in this life, receive good karmic retribution and, in past lives, be reborn with handsome features. Those who offer vegetarian feasts and provisions will, in this life, have abundant clothing and food and, in past lives, be reborn with dignified bearing. Those who give alms to the poor will, in this life, attain radiant perfection and, in past lives, be reborn with auspicious marks.

Those who refrain from consuming living beings will, in this life, enjoy freedom from illness and suffering and, in past lives, attain a long-lived body. Those who abstain from wine and meat will, in this life, have spirits that abide in their bodies and, in past lives, be reborn with the bodies of sages and worthies. Those who are free from craving and content with little will, in this life, have bodies free from foul odors and, in past lives, be reborn with pure bodies. Those who release life and ransom creatures will, in this life, be spared from premature death and, in past lives, be reborn with reverent bodies. Those who expound the teachings and transform others will, in this life, attain the dual cultivation of blessings and wisdom and, in past lives, be reborn with the bodies of renunciates.

Moreover, the retribution of meritorious deeds is like an echo responding to sound, like a shadow following form—no difference in magnitude, purity and turbidity naturally distinct. Yet you, in your ignorance and delusion, fail to recognize causes and conditions, disbelieve in the consequences of sin and merit, and do not understand that this body arises from the seeds of past blessings. You do not know that this body is but a fleeting apparition, that it is utterly illusory, that it is momentary and impermanent. Instead, you indulge in stinginess and greed, killing living beings, stealing, engaging in illicit sex and dissipation, consuming living creatures, uttering deceitful and frivolous speech, slandering the scriptures and teachings, amassing wealth—all the while believing this life has no limit.

Consider all beings: with eyes open, they commit countless sins; with eyes closed, they enter the prison of suffering. A lifetime of transgressions—when have they ever awakened? They cannot arouse a single thought of goodness to disperse the karmic deeds that bind them to past and future rebirths. Though they seek to liberate themselves, they plant the seeds of affliction, yet fret over their descendants, lamenting their lack of sustenance. I grieve for worldly people, who weep at the moment of death, yet from youth are consumed by worry for their sons and daughters, never recalling the kindness of their parents’ nurture. From time without beginning, they have imitated one another, never awakening, ever sinking deeper into ignorance.

I reflect further on all of you, who follow one another in folly, never self-aware. Thus I reveal the karmic causes and conditions of past lives, that you may emerge from the river of suffering and desire. I also lament that sentient beings drift and drown, never escaping the sea of suffering. This world is called the "Realm of Abandoned Worthies and Profit-Seeking," also known as the "Realm of Mixed Retribution." The heavens of desire and attachment arise within it, fleeting as lightning—appearing for a moment, then vanishing; briefly gathering, then scattering. Birth, aging, sickness, death; pain, itching, soreness, aching; hunger, cold, dryness, dampness; water, fire, blades, weapons; demonic spirits, thieves, poisonous winds, malignant diseases—all these afflictions intertwine, moment by moment impermanent, never abiding for even an instant. How much suffering! Yet even as these torments bind you in the present, you remain unaware—how then could you believe in the celestial realms, the blessed lands of immortals, the Dao of eternal life, and the freedom of non-action?

I observe that the lives of worldly beings are shorter than those of mayflies; their dwellings more cramped than a hair’s tip; their foulness more vile than excrement; their pleasures no different from those of dung-beetles. Yet they remain oblivious, mistaking this for happiness—is this not suffering? I further reflect that no one is born without prior karma. Thus, when examining the essence of spirit and form, each has its causes and conditions. Sin and merit, fortune and misfortune—all arise from karma. Therefore, longevity or premature death, nobility or lowliness, wealth or poverty, beauty or ugliness, foolishness or wisdom—each differs according to its kind, even among birds, beasts, insects, fish, chickens, dogs, grasses, and trees. How much more so for human birth, which is so rarely encountered! Once this body decays, when will it be regained after ten thousand kalpas?

Thus I earnestly admonish and exhort you: diligently cultivate precepts, fast, practice the Dao, recite scriptures, prostrate in worship, burn incense, light lamps, give alms, and repent. Vow to deliver the living and liberate the dead; create images and copy scriptures; establish temples and build bridges; dig wells by the roadside to aid travelers and relieve the thirsty. Through countless expedient means, pave the path for all beings in the future. What do I seek in this? All sentient beings should reflect deeply.

Today, in this grand assembly, as the scriptures teach and the Dharma reveals—whether in full or in part, beyond comprehension—we earnestly establish the foundation of blessings for ourselves and others, creating the path for the future. Now, as I bow in reverence and recite, let each of you be diligent. May these merits benefit all without limit, and may every sentient being receive their nourishment.

**Chapter Two: Repaying Kindness and Offering Merit**

Today, in this Daoist ritual, each member of the great assembly directs their heart and mind, reverently beseeching the Merciful Venerable One to universally bestow boundless merit and virtue upon all people. Now, the causes and effects of repaying kindness are expounded.

The master of repentance, so-and-so, humbly reflects and listens attentively to the scriptural words: When a person is born, Heaven and Earth serve as their model; they bear the yin and embrace the yang, receiving shelter within the womb, their life suspended by Heaven. The Heavenly Emperor then summons the Youth Who Records Lifespans to traverse the human realm, examining and measuring sins and blessings, the fortune or misfortune of men and women, the brevity or length of their lives. Every three days, a report is made; every seven days, a memorial is submitted; every hundred days, a record is finalized—unceasing even for a moment.

If one cultivates goodness and establishes merit, the Divine Youths of the Heavens, the Lords of Life and the Recorders of Deeds, will extend their years and eliminate calamities. If one commits sins and accumulates evil, the Heavenly Kings and the demonic spirits of the Six Heavens will seize their hun and po souls, bringing them before the Three Officials to have their consciousnesses collected. If one’s allotted lifespan is not fulfilled, it is due to the sins they have committed; if one completes their allotted lifespan, it is due to the goodness they have accumulated.

When a person seeks to extend their lifespan, it falls under the jurisdiction of the Earthly Offices. The various Heavens and Emperors examine and verify according to the registers, determining life and death. They then dispatch the officials of the Three Realms and the Youth Who Observes Life to gather the spirit and soul, cutting off the breath of life. If a person is afflicted by prolonged illness, bedridden and gravely stricken, their life nearing its end, and if their family and kin, according to their means, establish a Daoist ritual, recite scriptures, and perform repentance—regardless of the number of scrolls—the family and kin may reverently face the various Heavens and Sages, confessing the karmic offenses of the sick person’s embodied existence, thereby releasing their spirit and soul, extending their lifespan, and restoring them to health.

If the great limit of life is imminent, one may still be rescued through the performance of extensive merit and virtue, dedicating it to the departed soul to spare them from suffering and distress. The living will face no hardship or terror. From the first seventh-day period after death to the three annual commemorations, during the days of ancestral remembrance, offerings of incense and lamps should be made tirelessly, day and night.

Why is this so? There are also the Youths Who Observe Life who monitor and report sins and blessings. If one enters the gate of life, blessings flow to their descendants, they do not linger in hell, and they suffer no karmic retribution. It is like a person initially entangled in a legal dispute, where the case remains unresolved—this is analogous to the situation of the newly deceased.

Thus, two spirits, one of good and one of evil, descend every ten days to inspect the household. For those who perform merit, the good spirit will advocate for them, enabling rebirth in Heaven. For those who do not perform merit, the evil spirit will record their deeds, leading them into confinement, causing their family to experience much fear and misfortune. If there is suffering, one may go to a Daoist abbey or remain at home, facing the image of the Venerable One, bowing to the manifest and hidden transformations, performing purification rituals and practicing the Dao, redeeming karmic offenses to attain liberation. Their names will be inscribed in the registers of immortals, and their bodies will dwell in carefree joy.

Such are the various causes and effects of repaying kindness and offering merit, which are foremost and truly worthy of praise. If there are good men and good women who, for the sake of their parents and all their kin, paint or sculpt images, construct halls, and vow with sincere faith to widely encourage and exhort others—such actions are inconceivable. All people, within the various dharmas, who arouse a single good thought or make a single vow, harboring a heart of gratitude and repayment, are called good fruits, and are inconceivable.

Today, the great assembly in this Daoist ritual, as spoken in the scriptures, reverently beseech the Merciful Venerable One to expound this Dharma gate of merit and virtue for all sentient beings, serving as a path through life and death—this is inconceivable. The master of repentance, so-and-so, for the sake of their nine generations of ancestors, seven generations of forebears, parents, uncles, brothers, themselves, and all their kin—whether in hell, as hungry ghosts, as animals, or among all beings with consciousness—who have not yet received offerings or performed repayment, now wholeheartedly bows in reverence to the true and sacred beings invoked by name. May this merit and virtue pervade both the living and the deceased, enabling all to attain liberation.

Today, humbly for the sake of peace and the offering of merit through this repentance text, prostrating with the five limbs touching the ground, the heart directs its thoughts. Bowing to the Merciful Venerable One, I reverently bow to the true and sacred beings.

With sincere devotion, I bow to the Heavenly Worthy of Jade Clarity Who Bestows Blessings.
